trending.reason: Recent major announcement from industry leader OpenAI.
New analysis on influential tech critic Ed Zitron's dual roles in the AI industry.
New AI features in creative software
New research on neutron star mass limits.

articles.title: Sam Altman says OpenAI will have a 'legitimate AI researcher' by 2028
articles.author: Dave Ritchie
articles.fullContent:
TECHNOLOGY

Sam Altman says OpenAI will have a 'legitimate AI researcher' by 2028

CEO Sam Altman announced OpenAI expects to develop a fully automated AI researcher by 2028, with an intern-level version ready by 2026, signalling a new era of autonomous scientific discovery.

BY Dave Ritchie

OpenAI is on track to develop an intern-level AI research assistant by September 2026, escalating to a fully automated 'legitimate AI researcher' by 2028, CEO Sam Altman revealed in a recent announcement. This prediction underscores the company's rapid progress in deep learning systems, which are solving complex tasks at unprecedented speeds.

Altman's comments highlight internal metrics showing models are evolving faster than anticipated. Chief Scientist Jakub Pachocki clarified that this AI researcher is a sophisticated system designed to independently execute substantial research initiatives. This development is part of a broader strategy, as OpenAI recently transitioned to a public benefit corporation to allow for greater capital raising for its ambitious projects.

Accelerated Timelines
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has outlined an aggressive timeline for the development of autonomous AI research capabilities.

The Path to Superintelligence. Pachocki suggested that with these advancements, deep learning systems could potentially achieve superintelligence, outperforming humans in many critical areas, within the next ten years. To achieve this, OpenAI is focusing on algorithmic breakthroughs and massively increasing the computational power dedicated to problem-solving.

"Deep learning systems could potentially achieve superintelligence within the next ten years."

This pursuit of advanced AI is supported by significant financial commitments, including plans to develop 30 gigawatts of infrastructure, representing a potential $1.4 trillion obligation. These resources would enable an AI to dedicate immense computing power to solving single, complex problems, accelerating discoveries in science and medicine.

Sam Altman discusses the future trajectory of artificial intelligence and OpenAI's long-term vision in this interview.

The company's new structure aims to balance its ambitious research goals with a commitment to safety and responsible AI development. The move positions OpenAI to secure the necessary resources to build systems that could redefine scientific research and technological innovation.

Jakub Pachocki
Chief Scientist
Pachocki clarified the scope of the 'AI researcher' project.

By The Numbers

2026
Target for intern-level AI research assistant
2028
Target for fully automated AI researcher
$1.4T
Stated commitment for 30 GW of infrastructure

Key Context

OpenAI's timeline is part of a larger strategic vision following its restructuring into a public benefit corporation. This change allows it to raise significant capital for infrastructure-heavy projects aimed at achieving Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) and superintelligence.

The development of an autonomous AI researcher would mark a pivotal shift from AI as a tool to AI as an independent innovator, potentially accelerating progress in fields like medicine, physics, and technology.

A New Frontier in Research
The development of a fully autonomous AI researcher could represent a fundamental shift in how scientific discoveries are made.

articles.title: Ed Zitron Gets Paid to Love AI. He Also Gets Paid to Hate AI
articles.author: Wired Staff
articles.fullContent:
TECHNOLOGY

Ed Zitron Gets Paid to Love AI. He Also Gets Paid to Hate AI

A profile of Ed Zitron, a public relations professional known for his sharp critique of the overblown and misleading claims common in AI press releases.

BY Wired Staff

Public relations professional Ed Zitron has carved out a unique and controversial space in the tech world: he runs a PR firm, EZPR, that represents tech companies, while simultaneously being one of the most vocal and sharp-tongued critics of the artificial intelligence industry's hype. This dual role has led to a growing profile for Zitron, who uses his newsletter 'Where's Your Ed At' and podcast 'Better Offline' to dismantle what he sees as the unsubstantiated and often misleading claims from major AI players.

Zitron argues that the current wave of AI-related PR is filled with jargon and lacks substance, advocating for a more grounded and honest approach to communicating about technology. His critiques often focus on the financial unsustainability and exaggerated capabilities of generative AI models. He has famously referred to prominent tech CEOs as 'chunderfucks' and their promises as 'gobbledygook, nonsense, bullshit,' arguing that their companies burn through billions of dollars with no viable path to profitability.

The Critic
Ed Zitron has become a prominent voice questioning the AI industry's growth-at-all-costs mindset.

A Moral Language for Hating AIWhat sets Zitron apart from other AI skeptics is his focus on providing a 'moral language for hating generative AI'. He isn't a traditional doomer worried about superintelligence; instead, he frames his criticism in terms of business ethics and consumer harm. His 2023 newsletter on 'The Rot Economy' went viral for articulating how tech firms have prioritised growth over innovation and quality, a theme that continues in his AI commentary.

"I work with founders all the time... when you see these chunderfucks burning 5, 10 billion dollars in a year—and everyone's celebrating them? It's offensive."

Despite his harsh critiques, Zitron claims it hasn't cost him business, as he offers a blueprint for companies to build real products with sustainable value. He provides a counter-narrative to the dominant AI hype, attracting a significant following of those disillusioned with the tech industry's current trajectory.

In interviews and his podcast, Zitron frequently discusses what he terms the 'ROT economy' in the tech sector.
The Insider
Zitron leverages his PR industry experience to deconstruct tech narratives.

By The Numbers

70K+
Subscribers & listeners for his newsletter and podcast
$9B
Amount OpenAI burned in 2024, a frequent Zitron critique
2013
Year he founded his public relations agency, EZPR

Key Context

Ed Zitron's critique is part of a growing skepticism towards the 'growth-at-all-costs' mindset in Silicon Valley. He argues that the AI boom is a bubble, similar to past tech hypes, and that the business models of major players like OpenAI are fundamentally unsustainable.

His perspective is valued because, as a PR professional himself, he has deep insight into the mechanics of hype and media manipulation used by tech companies. This allows him to dissect press releases and CEO statements with an expert eye.

The Rot Economy
Zitron's viral thesis argues that technology firms have focused on growth above all else, harming innovation and consumers.

articles.title: Adobe launches AI assistants for Express and Photoshop
articles.author: Kyle Wiggers
articles.fullContent:
TECHNOLOGY

Adobe launches AI assistants for Express and Photoshop

Adobe has integrated new AI assistants into its Express and Photoshop applications to streamline creative workflows for users.

BY Kyle Wiggers

Adobe has introduced AI assistants into its Express and Photoshop software, aiming to simplify creative tasks for professionals and hobbyists alike.

In Adobe Express, a new artificial intelligence mode now allows users to generate complex images and unique designs simply by using text prompts. Photoshop's new assistant, which is currently available in a closed beta test, operates from a convenient side panel. It is designed to help creatives with repetitive and time-consuming tasks such as background removal and precise colour adjustments.

AI-Powered Design
The new AI assistant in Adobe Express simplifies image and design generation through text-based commands.

Beyond its current applications, Adobe is also exploring methods for cross-platform AI coordination. This initiative, known as 'Project Moonlight', aims to create a seamless creative experience across all of Adobe's products. Furthermore, the company is actively testing integrations with leading third-party AI models, including OpenAI's ChatGPT and Google's Gemini, to enhance the capabilities of its software suite.

A demonstration of the new AI assistant features integrated into Adobe's creative suite.

These developments signify a major step forward in Adobe's strategy to embed artificial intelligence deeply into its core products, promising to accelerate workflows and expand creative possibilities for millions of users worldwide.

Creative
Intelligence
Adobe is leveraging AI to automate complex tasks in Photoshop and other applications.

Key Context

Adobe's 'Project Moonlight' initiative is a significant part of its strategy, focusing on enabling AI features to work together across different applications.

The company is also collaborating with major AI developers like OpenAI and Google to bring the most advanced technologies, such as ChatGPT and Gemini, into its creative ecosystem.

The Future of Digital Art
The integration of advanced AI assistants is set to redefine the boundaries of digital creativity.

articles.title: Quantum 'echoes' reveal the potential of Google's quantum computer
articles.author: Emily Conover
articles.fullContent:
SCIENCE

Quantum 'echoes' reveal the potential of Google's quantum computer

Google's Willow quantum chip has demonstrated a verifiable quantum advantage, performing a calculation far beyond the reach of classical supercomputers.

BY Emily Conover

Google's Willow quantum chip has successfully performed a calculation reportedly out of reach for traditional supercomputers, achieving a key milestone known as quantum advantage.

The complex calculation, which measures a phenomenon called 'quantum echoes,' was completed on the Willow chip 13,000 times faster than it would take the Frontier supercomputer. This breakthrough is significant because the result can be independently verified for correctness, a critical step toward building reliable and practical quantum computers for real-world applications.

Quantum Architecture
Modern quantum processors like Google's Willow chip contain over 100 qubits.

This achievement marks a historic moment in computing. For the first time, a quantum computer has performed a complex, verifiable calculation faster than any supercomputer could. The algorithm, named Quantum Echoes, helps scientists study how information spreads in quantum systems, which could pave the way for discoveries in drug development and materials science.

"The result can be verified for correctness, which is a vital step toward the practical and reliable application of quantum computers for real-world problems."

Unlike the 'quantum supremacy' claim in 2019, which faced criticism for its lack of practical application, this demonstration of 'verifiable quantum advantage' focuses on a repeatable and useful task. The verification process ensures the answer is not just fast but also correct, overcoming a major hurdle in the field of quantum computing.

A visual explanation of the principles behind quantum computing.

The success of the Quantum Echoes algorithm on the Willow chip moves quantum computing from a theoretical spectacle to a tangible, verifiable tool for scientific exploration.

The Qubit
Building Block of Quantum Power
A qubit, or quantum bit, is the basic unit of quantum information.

By The Numbers

13,000x
Faster than a classical supercomputer for this specific task
100+
Qubits utilised in Google's Willow processor
100%
Verifiable results, ensuring accuracy alongside speed

Key Context

Quantum advantage occurs when a quantum computer solves a problem that a classical computer practically cannot. Verifiability ensures the answer is not just fast, but also correct, overcoming a major hurdle in quantum computing.

This breakthrough could accelerate research in fields like medicine, materials science, and fundamental physics by allowing scientists to simulate molecular interactions with unprecedented accuracy.

A New Era for Computation
The demonstration of verifiable quantum advantage signals a shift from theoretical research to practical application in quantum computing.

articles.title: Quantum Teleportation Achieved Using Entangled Particles
articles.author: Ancient Origins
images: data:image/svg+xml;utf8,<svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg' viewBox='0 0 800 600' width='800' height='600'><defs><linearGradient id='grad' x1='0%' y1='0%' x2='100%' y2='100%'><stop offset='0%' style='stop-color:rgb(48, 7, 107);stop-opacity:1' /><stop offset='100%' style='stop-color:rgb(12, 53, 106);stop-opacity:1' /></linearGradient></defs><rect width='800' height='600' fill='url(#grad)'/><text x='50%' y='50%' fill='white' font-family='sans-serif' font-size='32' text-anchor='middle' dominant-baseline='middle'>Quantum Teleportation Schematic</text></svg>
articles.fullContent:
SCIENCE

Quantum Teleportation Achieved Using Entangled Particles

Scientists have successfully transferred the quantum state of photons and atoms, proving that teleportation is a reality in the subatomic world through a phenomenon known as quantum entanglement.

BY Ancient Origins

Quantum teleportation is a reality, enabling the instantaneous transfer of a particle's quantum state across any distance. Scientists have now successfully teleported photons, atoms, and ions using the principle of quantum entanglement, marking a significant milestone in physics.

This groundbreaking process transfers information—the precise quantum state of a particle—rather than matter itself. It relies on quantum entanglement, a counter-intuitive phenomenon where two particles become linked, mirroring each other's state instantly, regardless of the distance separating them. While the teleportation of a human being remains firmly in the realm of science fiction, these successful experiments represent a major leap forward in our understanding and application of quantum mechanics.

Bridging Distances Instantly
The concept of teleportation, once science fiction, is now a proven phenomenon at the quantum level.

The Core Principle: Entanglement is the engine behind this feat. Albert Einstein famously called it 'spooky action at a distance.' When two particles are entangled, a measurement performed on one particle instantaneously influences the other, a principle that defies classical physics but is a cornerstone of quantum theory. This allows for the 'disembodied' transfer of information from one location to another.

"Any interaction with one particle instantly affects the other, regardless of the distance separating them."
A detailed explanation of how quantum teleportation works and its implications for future technology.

The successful experiments involved the teleportation of photons, atoms, and ions, demonstrating the viability of this method across different types of quantum particles. These advancements pave the way for future technologies such as ultra-secure quantum communication networks and powerful quantum computers.

Quantum
Connections
Entangled particles remain connected no matter how far apart.

By The Numbers

2
Particles linked via quantum entanglement
3
Types of particles successfully teleported (photons, atoms, ions)
∞
Effective distance of entanglement (instantaneous)

Key Context

Quantum teleportation does not violate the principle that nothing can travel faster than light. It is the information about the state that is transferred, not the particle itself. The process still requires a classical communication channel to complete the transfer, which is limited by the speed of light.

These experiments are foundational for developing next-generation quantum computing and secure communication networks.

articles.title: How Compact Can a Neutron Star Get Before Collapsing Into a Black Hole?
articles.author: Keith Cooper
articles.fullContent:
SPACE

How Compact Can a Neutron Star Get Before Collapsing Into a Black Hole?

New research provides an updated estimate for the mass limit that prevents the universe's densest objects from collapsing into singularities.

BY Keith Cooper

Two independent teams of researchers have established a new, refined estimate for the maximum mass a neutron star can attain before it must collapse into a black hole. This critical limit, known as the Tolman-Oppenheimer-Volkoff (TOV) limit, is fundamental to understanding the final stages of stellar evolution and the birth of black holes.

Neutron stars are the incredibly dense remnants of massive stars that have exploded as supernovae. They are surpassed in density only by black holes themselves, packing a mass greater than our sun into a sphere just a few kilometres in diameter. Until now, pinning down the exact mass at which a neutron star's internal pressure can no longer withstand its own gravity has been a significant challenge for astrophysicists.

Densest Objects
An artist's rendering of a magnetar, a special type of neutron star. The new mass limit applies to all non-rotating neutron stars.

Universal Calculations have played a key role in defining the new maximum mass. By combining theoretical models with observational data from events like the merging of two neutron stars, scientists can make calculations that are independent of the specific equation of state, which describes the exotic matter inside the star. This provides a more robust and reliable upper limit.

"If a neutron star stays below that Oppenheimer limit, it will remain in that state. If it grows more massive, then it collapses into a black hole."

The updated findings suggest a non-rotating neutron star cannot exceed a mass of around 2.25 solar masses. Should a neutron star accrete more matter and surpass this threshold, its collapse into a black hole is inevitable. This refined figure helps astronomers better classify compact objects observed via gravitational waves, distinguishing between massive neutron stars and the lightest black holes.

A visual explanation of what neutron stars are and their place in the cosmos.

This research has significant implications for astrophysics. By providing a more precise mass cutoff, it helps explain the observed 'mass gap' between the heaviest known neutron stars (around 2.35 solar masses) and the lightest black holes. It also offers a new method to test the underlying cosmological model of the universe.

Stellar
Endgames
A neutron star's fate is determined by its mass.

By The Numbers

2.25 M☉
New estimated maximum mass of a neutron star before collapse.
~1.4 M☉
Typical mass of most observed neutron stars.
~10 km
The approximate radius of a typical neutron star.
2.35 M☉
Mass of the most massive neutron star detected so far (PSR J0952–0607).

Key Context

The Tolman-Oppenheimer-Volkoff (TOV) limit is the upper bound to the mass of cold, non-rotating neutron stars. The extreme pressure inside these stars causes protons and electrons to combine into neutrons. This neutron-degenerate matter creates an outward pressure that resists gravity, but only up to a point. Beyond the TOV limit, no known force can prevent gravitational collapse into a black hole.

The Point of No Return
Understanding the boundary between the densest stars and the simplest black holes is a major goal of modern astrophysics.

articles.title: Egypt's Forbidden Archaeological Site: Military Lockdown Hides Complex
articles.author: Ancient Origins

articles.fullContent:
ARCHAEOLOGY-AND-HISTORY

Egypt's Forbidden Archaeological Site: Military Lockdown Hides Complex

The archaeological site of Zawyet El Aryan, near the Giza Pyramids, has been a restricted military zone since the 1960s, preventing modern investigation.

BY Ancient Origins

The mysterious archaeological site of Zawyet El Aryan has been under a military lockdown since the 1960s, preventing any modern scientific investigation of its enigmatic underground structures. Located just three miles from the Giza Pyramids, this restriction has led to it being nicknamed 'Egypt's Area 51'.

The site is dominated by a massive pit carved deep into the limestone bedrock, which is lined with enormous blocks of granite. The only comprehensive record of this complex comes from photographs taken by Italian archaeologist Alessandro Barsanti in the early 1900s. Without new access, the true purpose of the structure—believed by some to be an unfinished pyramid—remains one of Egypt's most profound mysteries.

Early Excavation
A photograph from Alessandro Barsanti's work in the early 1900s, one of the only records of the site's interior.
"This restriction has prevented any modern scientific investigation of its enigmatic underground structures."

Early records are the only window into the complex. Barsanti's century-old photographs are the sole detailed documentation of what lies beneath the now-restricted zone. The military installation has since expanded, with facilities built over parts of the original necropolis, further complicating future research. Inside the main pit, an unusual oval granite vat was discovered sealed within a chamber, though its contents are now lost.

A video exploration of the theories and history surrounding the sealed Zawyet El Aryan complex.

The purpose of the construction remains a topic of intense debate among archaeologists and researchers. While some theories suggest it was an unfinished pyramid complex for a Fourth Dynasty pharaoh, the unique design and lack of an above-ground structure challenge conventional explanations.

Forbidden
Territory
The site has been inaccessible for nearly six decades.

By The Numbers

3 mi
Distance from the Giza Pyramids
1960s
Site lockdown by the military began
100 ft
Depth of the T-shaped pit carved into limestone

Key Context

The only detailed understanding of Zawyet El Aryan comes from the work of Alessandro Barsanti in the early 20th century. His photographs and records are invaluable because no modern archaeological work has been permitted since 1964, leaving the site in a state of arrested discovery.

A Legacy in Stone
The unresolved questions about Zawyet El Aryan continue to challenge our understanding of ancient Egyptian engineering and purpose.

articles.title: Solved: The Mystery of the Spiraling Holes in the Nasca Region of Peru
articles.author: Joanna Gillan
articles.fullContent:
ARCHAEOLOGY

Solved: The Mystery of the Spiraling Holes in the Nasca Region of Peru

The spiraling holes in the Nasca region of Peru, known as puquios, were part of a sophisticated hydraulic system built by the ancient Nasca people.

BY Joanna Gillan

The mysterious spiraling holes found in the Nasca region of Peru, known as puquios, have been identified as part of a complex and sophisticated hydraulic system built by the ancient Nasca people.

This advanced network of aqueducts was constructed to retrieve water from underground aquifers, allowing the Nasca to establish a thriving agricultural system in one of the driest climates on Earth. The unique spiral shape of the puquios was ingeniously designed to allow wind to enter the canals, which helped to force water from the subterranean sources to the areas where it was needed for irrigation and daily life.

The Nasca region is famous not only for the puquios but also for its enormous geoglyphs, known as the Nasca Lines.

A feat of ancient engineering, the puquio system demonstrates a deep understanding of geology and water dynamics. By tapping into deep underground water sources, the Nasca civilization could sustain itself for centuries in an otherwise inhospitable environment, showcasing their remarkable ingenuity and resilience.

"This network of aqueducts was constructed by the ancient Nasca people to retrieve water from underground aquifers."
This video explores the construction and function of the ancient puquio system in the Nazca desert.

The continued operation of some of these aqueducts today is a testament to the quality of their original construction. They stand as a significant archaeological treasure, providing invaluable insights into the technological capabilities and societal organisation of the pre-Hispanic Nazca people who flourished between 100 BC and 800 AD.

Nasca's Enduring
Legacy
The iconic 'Hummingbird' geoglyph is one of over 700 figures etched into the desert floor.

By The Numbers

36+
Functioning puquios still in use today
1,500+
Years old, built by the Nasca culture
1-4
Inches of annual rainfall in the region

Key Context

The puquios are a key part of the larger Nazca cultural landscape, which also includes the world-renowned Nazca Lines. This hydraulic system was fundamental to the survival and prosperity of the Nazca civilization, enabling agriculture and settlement in the arid coastal desert of southern Peru.

Tapping the Desert's Hidden Water
The spiral design allowed for maintenance and also harnessed wind to help draw water along the underground channels.

articles.title: Secret Inscription Reveals High Status of Rusty Renaissance Sword
articles.author: Ancient Origins
articles.fullContent:
ARCHAEOLOGY

Secret Inscription Reveals High Status of Rusty Renaissance Sword

A hidden inscription on a heavily corroded 16th-century sword has been revealed using modern CT scanning technology, identifying its maker and confirming the artifact's high status.

BY Ancient Origins

Researchers have discovered a hidden inscription on a heavily corroded 16th-century sword using computed tomography (CT) scanning. This non-invasive technique allowed scientists to see beneath layers of rust without damaging the artifact, revealing the signature of a master craftsman and illuminating the history of the high-status weapon.

The sword was recovered from the historic Collegium Jenense in Jena, Germany, the original site of the University of Jena which was founded in 1548. The CT scans unveiled the signature 'Clemes Stam,' identifying the blade as the work of a documented swordsmith from Solingen. During the Renaissance, Solingen was a renowned European centre for blade-making, supplying weapons to nobility across the continent.

The Corroded Sword
The 16th-century sword as it appeared before the non-invasive CT scanning analysis revealed its secrets.

A Window into the Past. The use of industrial CT scanning in archaeology is a revolutionary step, allowing for the virtual excavation of artifacts. This technology creates high-resolution 3D models, making internal structures and hidden details visible without physical intervention. The discovery on the Jena sword demonstrates how 21st-century imaging can solve historical mysteries.

"CT doesn't just capture surface details; it reveals the object's inner story. In this case, it literally uncovered a name that connects Jena to the European tradition of sword-making."

The intricate craftsmanship, likely a form of damascening, indicated the sword was a premium piece commissioned by an individual of considerable wealth. Given its burial location, researchers believe it may have belonged to a university rector or a student of noble lineage.

A demonstration of computed tomography (CT) technology, similar to the method used to analyse the Renaissance sword.

Concluding the analysis, the project successfully preserved the artifact while adding a significant chapter to the university's history. The find connects Jena's academic past to the wider European network of Renaissance-era arms production, showcasing how modern innovation can give a voice to silent objects from the past.

Renaissance
Craftsmanship
Swords from this era were symbols of status as well as functional weapons.

By The Numbers

16th
Century origin of the sword
1548
Founding year of the Collegium Jenense
4
Swords discovered among the grave goods

Key Context

The Collegium Jenense was not only the heart of the University of Jena but also served as a burial ground for professors and students between 1594 and 1814. The recovery of swords as grave goods signifies the high social status of the deceased. The decision to use non-destructive CT scanning was crucial, as traditional cleaning methods could have destroyed the fragile inscription.

Bridging Past and Present
Modern technology is a critical tool for cultural heritage, allowing researchers to uncover and preserve history without destructive methods.
